articles.headline: Mattel Official Delivers an Apology in China
articles.snippet: An executive reportedly apologized for maligning Chinese manufacturers in the course of toy recalls, but the company said the remarks were misconstrued.
articles.abstract: An executive reportedly apologized for maligning Chinese manufacturers in the course of toy recalls, but the company said the remarks were misconstrued.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mattel, the world’s largest toy maker, apologized in China yesterday for its recalls of nearly 20 million Chinese-made toys this summer.

articles.headline: The World Comes to Georgia, and an Old Church Adapts
articles.snippet: An influx of immigrants and refugees to Clarkston, Ga., sparked a battle that led a church to change both its name and its mission.
articles.abstract: An influx of immigrants and refugees to Clarkston, Ga., sparked a battle that led a church to change both its name and its mission.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLARKSTON, Ga., Sept. 21 — When the Rev. Phil Kitchin steps into the pulpit of the Clarkston International Bible Church on Sunday mornings, he stands eye to eye with the changing face of America. In the pews before him, alongside white-haired Southern women in their Sunday best, sit immigrants from the Philippines and Togo, refugees from war-scarred Liberia, Ethiopia and Sudan, even a convert from Afghanistan.

articles.headline: Beyond the Reservation
articles.snippet: Buoyed by hundreds of millions of dollars in annual profits from their gambling businesses, Indian tribes are looking farther afield for places to invest their casino wealth.
articles.abstract: Buoyed by hundreds of millions of dollars in annual profits from their gambling businesses, Indian tribes are looking farther afield for places to invest their casino wealth.
articles.lead_paragraph: MASHANTUCKET PEQUOT INDIAN RESERVATION, Conn. — With hundreds of millions of dollars in annual profits flowing in from their gambling business, the Mashantucket Pequots first floated the idea of building a large amusement park. But those plans were shot down by neighbors already unhappy with the huge Foxwoods casino in their midst.

articles.headline: In Campaign, Money Chase Circles Globe
articles.snippet: Candidates are seeking out wealthy Americans overseas, especially in financial centers like London and Hong Kong.
articles.abstract: Candidates are seeking out wealthy Americans overseas, especially in financial centers like London and Hong Kong.
articles.lead_paragraph: The intense pursuit of money in the presidential campaigns and the many wealthy Americans working at hedge funds and other businesses worldwide have led candidates to broaden fund-raising overseas, especially financial centers like London and Hong Kong.
articles.byline: By Russ Buettner and Marc Santora

articles.headline: Wary Buyers May Scuttle Two Deals
articles.snippet: Two more private equity deals showed signs of unraveling on Friday, as buyers and bankers grow increasingly wary of the purchases they rushed into only months ago.
articles.abstract: Two more private equity deals showed signs of unraveling on Friday, as buyers and bankers grow increasingly wary of the purchases they rushed into only months ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two more private equity deals showed signs of unraveling yesterday, as buyers and bankers grow increasingly wary of the multibillion-dollar purchases they rushed into only months ago.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: This Climate Is Surely Full of Hot Air
articles.snippet: Recent efforts to force corporate changes on global warming are misguided environmental grandstanding.
articles.abstract: Recent efforts to force corporate changes on global warming are misguided environmental grandstanding.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sometimes the only thing to do is just state the obvious. So here goes: The climate change petition that was promoted last week as a boon for investors and for the environment has almost no chance of ever being adopted. Wait — did I say almost? I take it back. It has no chance. Zero. Zilch. None.

articles.headline: Analyzing Failure Beforehand
articles.snippet: Should businesses replace post-mortems with “pre-mortems?” Adopt “counterintuitive management practices?” And more...
articles.abstract: Should businesses replace post-mortems with “pre-mortems?” Adopt “counterintuitive management practices?” And more...
articles.lead_paragraph: Post-mortems, trying to figure out why a new idea failed, are a common business process. But wouldn’t “pre-mortems” make more sense?

articles.headline: Chileans Order Peru’s Ex-Chief Home for Trial
articles.snippet: The ruling on Peru’s former president, Alberto Fujimori, may have broader influence, experts said.
articles.abstract: The ruling on Peru’s former president, Alberto Fujimori, may have broader influence, experts said.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 21 — Chile’s Supreme Court on Friday approved the extradition of Peru’s former president, Alberto K. Fujimori, on charges of human rights abuses and corruption during his time in power in the 1990s.

articles.headline: Israeli Raid on Syria Fuels Debate on Weapons
articles.snippet: Whether Syria is starting a nuclear program, as Israel may believe, is a difficult question for U.S. spy agencies.
articles.abstract: Whether Syria is starting a nuclear program, as Israel may believe, is a difficult question for U.S. spy agencies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 — American concerns about ties between Syria and North Korea have long focused on a partnership involving missiles and missile technology. Even many hawks within the Bush administration have expressed doubts that the Syrians have the money or technical depth to build a serious nuclear program like the one in Iran.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: In Shift, Bush Emerges as a Budget Warrior
articles.snippet: President Bush is now portraying himself as a fiscal conservative as he heads into a spending battle with Democrats.
articles.abstract: President Bush is now portraying himself as a fiscal conservative as he heads into a spending battle with Democrats.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 — George W. Bush ran for the White House as a compassionate conservative. Now he is portraying himself as a conservative of a different stripe — the fiscal kind.

articles.headline: Is Private Equity Giving Hertz a Boost?
articles.snippet: Since its initial public offering in November, Hertz’s shares have risen 43 percent, surprising investors who thought there was little value left in the company.
articles.abstract: Since its initial public offering in November, Hertz’s shares have risen 43 percent, surprising investors who thought there was little value left in the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAST fall, Mark P. Frissora, the newly hired chief executive of Hertz, kept running into the same question from potential investors.

articles.headline: Guess Who’s Feeling the Mortgage Pain
articles.snippet: Nine months into the meltdown of the home loan market, investors are still waiting for banks, brokerage firms and other companies to come clean on losses.
articles.abstract: Nine months into the meltdown of the home loan market, investors are still waiting for banks, brokerage firms and other companies to come clean on losses.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENIAL is a powerful thing, and nowhere is that more evident than among companies holding mortgage securities that are on the skids. Nine months into the meltdown of the home loan market, investors are still waiting for banks, brokerage firms and other companies to come clean on losses incurred on those securities.

articles.headline: Nuance and Resolve in Rulings by Attorney General Nominee
articles.snippet: A look at 18 years of Judge Michael B. Mukasey’s opinions reveals a complex temperament and legal philosophy.
articles.abstract: A look at 18 years of Judge Michael B. Mukasey’s opinions reveals a complex temperament and legal philosophy.
articles.lead_paragraph: In his 18 years on the federal bench, Judge Michael B. Mukasey issued more than 1,500 decisions concerning matters as cataclysmic as the Holocaust and as mundane as milk, beer and cigarettes.

articles.headline: From Russia With Cash: Seeding a Hedge Fund
articles.snippet: Andrei Vavilov — energy magnate and nascent hedge fund manager — says he’s in the right spot if Russia invests oil money.
articles.abstract: Andrei Vavilov — energy magnate and nascent hedge fund manager — says he’s in the right spot if Russia invests oil money.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANDREI VAVILOV — Russian multimillionaire, well-connected energy magnate and nascent hedge fund manager — smiles broadly in a Manhattan restaurant as a lawyer, a lobbyist, an economist and a former congressman praise him over shots of vodka and a lavish spread of lamb, salmon and beef tenderloin.

articles.headline: Welcome or Not, Orthodoxy Is Back in Russia’s Public Schools
articles.snippet: The drive by a revitalized Russian Orthodox Church to weave its tenets into the education system has prompted a backlash.
articles.abstract: The drive by a revitalized Russian Orthodox Church to weave its tenets into the education system has prompted a backlash.
articles.lead_paragraph: KOLOMNA, Russia — One of the most discordant debates in Russian society is playing out in public schools like those in this city not far from Moscow, where the other day a teacher named Irina Donshina set aside her textbooks, strode before her second graders and, as if speaking from a pulpit, posed a simple question:

articles.headline: At Many Homes, More Profit and Less Nursing
articles.snippet: Insulated from lawsuits by their corporate structures, private investors in nursing homes have cut expenses and staff, sometimes below minimum requirements.
articles.abstract: Insulated from lawsuits by their corporate structures, private investors in nursing homes have cut expenses and staff, sometimes below minimum requirements.
articles.lead_paragraph: Habana Health Care Center, a 150-bed nursing home in Tampa, Fla., was struggling when a group of large private investment firms purchased it and 48 other nursing homes in 2002.

articles.headline: Security Firm Faces Criminal Charges in Iraq
articles.snippet: The Iraqi government plans to refer charges to its courts within days in the killing of at least eight Iraqis.
articles.abstract: The Iraqi government plans to refer charges to its courts within days in the killing of at least eight Iraqis.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Sept. 22 — The Iraqi government said Saturday that it expects to refer criminal charges to its courts within days in connection with a shooting here by a private American security company, and the Interior Ministry gave new details of six other episodes it is investigating involving the company.
articles.byline: By James Glanz and Sabrina Tavernise

articles.headline: We Love Our Jobs. Just Ask Us.
articles.snippet: The key to identifying a good workplace is asking the people who work there.
articles.abstract: The key to identifying a good workplace is asking the people who work there.
articles.lead_paragraph: TWENTY-FIVE years ago, I started to work on a book whose optimistic title was “The 100 Best Companies to Work for in America.” I say optimistic because my writing partner, Robert Levering, and I weren’t sure that we could find 100 worthy workplaces.

articles.headline: Clinton Solidifies Edge as Rivals Take a Tougher Line
articles.snippet: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s rivals for the Democratic nomination have begun rolling out aggressive new strategies aimed primarily at her.
articles.abstract: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s rivals for the Democratic nomination have begun rolling out aggressive new strategies aimed primarily at her.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Varying Paths in a Wide Open G.O.P. Lineup
articles.snippet: The race for the Republican  nomination remains remarkably fluid, with key constituencies having yet to settle on a candidate.
articles.abstract: The race for the Republican  nomination remains remarkably fluid, with key constituencies having yet to settle on a candidate.
articles.lead_paragraph: The race for the Republican presidential nomination remains remarkably fluid, with important constituencies like evangelical voters having yet to settle on a candidate, and the late entrance of former Senator Fred D. Thompson generating little excitement.
articles.byline: By Michael Cooper and Michael Luo

articles.headline: Glimpses of a Shadowy World in Pakistan
articles.snippet: The arrest of a Pakistani-born German citizen offers glimpses of the traffic into the tribal areas of Pakistan and the attempt by the authorities to monitor it.
articles.abstract: The arrest of a Pakistani-born German citizen offers glimpses of the traffic into the tribal areas of Pakistan and the attempt by the authorities to monitor it.
articles.lead_paragraph: STUTTGART, Germany, Sept. 17 — Aleem Nasir, a 45-year-old German citizen who was held for two months this summer in Pakistan and interrogated by Pakistani and Western agents about terrorism-related activities, concedes that “they have their right to be worried about me.”
articles.byline: By Michael Moss and Souad Mekhennet

articles.headline: Savor Those Curly Fries: Planet Hollywood Is Back (Again)
articles.snippet: Planet Hollywood has stood as a cautionary tale about the perils of celebrity and hype. But its founder, Robert Earl, hopes a new casino will be the crown jewel of its resurrection.
articles.abstract: Planet Hollywood has stood as a cautionary tale about the perils of celebrity and hype. But its founder, Robert Earl, hopes a new casino will be the crown jewel of its resurrection.
articles.lead_paragraph: The celebrity investors were all smiles for the groundbreaking of the Planet Hollywood casino in Las Vegas, Sly, Bruce, Demi and Arnold among them. “It was a lot of pomp and circumstance,” Sylvester Stallone recalled. “I think there was a gold shovel.”

articles.headline: As the Fall Season Arrives, TV Screens Get More Cluttered
articles.snippet: Snipes — promotional ads for TV programs that share the screen with other programs — are just the latest effort by network executives to cram promotions onto television screens.
articles.abstract: Snipes — promotional ads for TV programs that share the screen with other programs — are just the latest effort by network executives to cram promotions onto television screens.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kyra Sedgwick, star of “The Closer” on TNT, walks under a police tape and scans the screen with her flashlight. And every time she does, she makes Gretchen Corbin, a technical writer in Berkeley, Calif., irate.

articles.headline: Company Will Monitor Phone Calls to Tailor Ads
articles.snippet: Pudding Media is introducing an Internet phone service that will be supported by advertising related to what people are talking about during their calls.
articles.abstract: Pudding Media is introducing an Internet phone service that will be supported by advertising related to what people are talking about during their calls.
articles.lead_paragraph: Companies like Google scan their e-mail users’ in-boxes to deliver ads related to those messages. Will people be as willing to let a company listen in on their phone conversations to do the same?

articles.headline: Graft in Military Contracts Spread From Base
articles.snippet: Pentagon inquiries into some $6 billion in contracts for possible corruption have resulted in the suicides of at least two officers among scores of suspects.
articles.abstract: Pentagon inquiries into some $6 billion in contracts for possible corruption have resulted in the suicides of at least two officers among scores of suspects.
articles.lead_paragraph: CASTOR, La. — On the fourth Sunday in July, John Lee Cockerham was here in his hometown for the baptism of his twin sons.
articles.byline: By Ginger Thompson and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Buy a Laptop for a Child, Get Another Laptop Free
articles.snippet: One Laptop Per Child, an ambitious project to bring computing to the developing world’s children, is reaching out to the public through an interesting marketing campaign.
articles.abstract: One Laptop Per Child, an ambitious project to bring computing to the developing world’s children, is reaching out to the public through an interesting marketing campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: One Laptop Per Child, an ambitious project to bring computing to the developing world’s children, has considerable momentum. Years of work by engineers and scientists have paid off in a pioneering low-cost machine that is light, rugged and surprisingly versatile. The early reviews have been glowing, and mass production is set to start next month.

articles.headline: TV Remote Moves Over for a Mouse
articles.snippet: With a new fall season getting under way, will audiences leave behind the tyranny of the broadcast schedule and make up their own fall television schedule by downloading?
articles.abstract: With a new fall season getting under way, will audiences leave behind the tyranny of the broadcast schedule and make up their own fall television schedule by downloading?
articles.lead_paragraph: Media consumers have said, loudly and repeatedly, that they want to watch what they want, when and where they want it. Last week NBC called that bluff, saying that its prime-time broadcast schedule would be there for free downloading for a week after being shown on television.

articles.headline: Dodd’s Other Campaign: Restoring Dad’s Reputation
articles.snippet: Senator Christopher Dodd’s 2008 campaign is the most public chapter in his quest for his father’s redemption.
articles.abstract: Senator Christopher Dodd’s 2008 campaign is the most public chapter in his quest for his father’s redemption.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 — On June 23, 1967, Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, was censured by the United States Senate for diverting $116,000 in campaign funds for his personal use. The vote was 92 to 5.

articles.headline: Monks’ Protest Is Challenging Burmese Junta
articles.snippet: Onlookers cheered Buddhist monks in the largest protests in two decades against Myanmar’s military rulers.
articles.abstract: Onlookers cheered Buddhist monks in the largest protests in two decades against Myanmar’s military rulers.
articles.lead_paragraph: BANGKOK, Monday, Sept. 24 — The largest street protests in two decades against Myanmar’s military rulers gained momentum Sunday as thousands of onlookers cheered huge columns of Buddhist monks and shouted support for the detained pro-democracy leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi.
